objects.moduledoc:
This is the 3D mathematics library for graphmath.

This submodule handles 3x3 matrices using tuples of floats.

This is the 3D mathematics library for graphmath.

This submodule handles 4x4 matrices using tuples of floats.

This is the 2D mathematics library for graphmath.

This submodule handles vectors stored as a tuple.

This is the 3D mathematics library for graphmath.

This submodule handles 3D vectors using tuples of floats.

objects.name: add
objects.doc:
`add(a,b)` adds one `mat33` to another `mat33`.

`a` is the first `mat33`.

`b` is the second `mat33`.

This returns a `mat33` which is the element-wise sum of `a` and `b`.

objects.name: apply
objects.doc:
`apply( a, v )` transforms a `vec3` by a `mat33`.

`a` is the `mat33` to transform by.

`v` is the `vec3` to be transformed.

This returns a `vec3` representing **A****v**.

This is the "full" application of a matrix, and uses all elements.

objects.name: apply_left
objects.doc:
`apply_left( v, a )` transforms a `vec3` by a `mat33`, applied on the left.

`a` is the `mat33` to transform by.

`v` is the `vec3` to be transformed.

This returns a `vec3` representing **v****A**.

This is the "full" application of a matrix, and uses all elements.

objects.name: apply_left_transpose
objects.doc:
`apply_left_transpose( v, a )` transforms a `vec3` by a transposed `mat33`, applied on the left.

`a` is the `mat33` to transform by.

`v` is the `vec3` to be transformed.

This returns a `vec3` representing **v****A**<sup>T</sup>.

This is the "full" application of a matrix, and uses all elements.

objects.name: apply_transpose
objects.doc:
`apply_transpose( a, v )` transforms a `vec3` by a a transposed `mat33`.

`a` is the `mat33` to transform by.

`v` is the `vec3` to be transformed.

This returns a `vec3` representing **A**<sup>T</sup>**v**.

This is the "full" application of a matrix, and uses all elements.

objects.name: at
objects.doc:
`at( a, i, j)` selects an element of a `mat33`.

`a` is the `mat33` to index.

`i` is the row integer index [1,3].

`j` is the column integer index [1,3].

This returns a float from the matrix at row `i` and column `j`.

objects.name: column0
objects.doc:
`column0( a )` selects the first column of a `mat33`.

`a` is the `mat33` to take the first column of.

This returns a `vec3` representing the first column of `a`.

objects.name: column1
objects.doc:
`column1( a )` selects the second column of a `mat33`.

`a` is the `mat33` to take the second column of.

This returns a `vec3` representing the second column of `a`.

objects.name: column2
objects.doc:
`column2( a )` selects the third column of a `mat33`.

`a` is the `mat33` to take the third column of.

This returns a `vec3` representing the third column of `a`.

objects.name: diag
objects.doc:
`diag( a )` selects the diagonal of a `mat33`.

`a` is the `mat33` to take the diagonal of.

This returns a `vec3` representing the diagonal of `a`.

objects.name: identity
objects.doc:
`identity()` creates an identity `mat33`.

This returns an identity `mat33`.

objects.name: make_rotate
objects.doc:
`make_rotate( theta )` creates a mat33 that rotates a vec2 by `theta` radians about the +Z axis.

`theta` is the float of the number of radians of rotation the matrix will provide.

This returns a `mat33` which rotates by `theta` radians about the +Z axis.

objects.name: make_scale
objects.doc:
`make_scale( k )` creates a `mat33` that uniformly scales.

`k` is the float value to scale by.

This returns a `mat33` whose diagonal is all `k`s.

objects.name: make_scale
objects.doc:
`make_scale( sx, sy, sz )` creates a `mat33` that scales each axis independently.

`sx` is a float for scaling the x-axis.

`sy` is a float for scaling the y-axis.

`sz` is a float for scaling the z-axis.

This returns a `mat33` whose diagonal is `{ sx, sy, sz }`.

Note that, when used with `vec2`s via the *transform* method, `sz` will have no effect.

objects.name: make_translate
objects.doc:
`make_translate( tx, ty )` creates a mat33 that translates a vec2 by (tx, ty).

`tx` is a float for translating along the x-axis.

`ty` is a float for translating along the y-axis

This returns a `mat33` which translates by a vec2 `{ tx, ty }`.

objects.name: multiply
objects.doc:
`multiply( a, b )` multiply two matrices a and b together.

`a` is the `mat33` multiplicand.

`b` is the `mat33` multiplier.

This returns the `mat33` product of the `a` and `b`.

objects.name: multiply_transpose
objects.doc:
`multiply_transpose( a, b )` multiply two matrices a and b<sup>T</sup> together.

`a` is the `mat33` multiplicand.

`b` is the `mat33` multiplier.

This returns the `mat33` product of the `a` and `b`<sup>T</sup>.

objects.name: round
objects.doc:
`round( a, sigfigs )` rounds every element of a `mat33` to some number of decimal places.

`a` is the `mat33` to round.

`sigfigs` is an integer on [0,15] of the number of decimal places to round to.

This returns a `mat33` which is the result of rounding `a`.

objects.name: row0
objects.doc:
`row0( a )` selects the first row of a `mat33`.

`a` is the `mat33` to take the first row of.

This returns a `vec3` representing the first row of `a`.

objects.name: row1
objects.doc:
`row1( a )` selects the second row of a `mat33`.

`a` is the `mat33` to take the second row of.

This returns a `vec3` representing the second row of `a`.

objects.name: row2
objects.doc:
`row2( a )` selects the third row of a `mat33`.

`a` is the `mat33` to take the third row of.

This returns a `vec3` representing the third row of `a`.

objects.name: scale
objects.doc:
`scale( a, k )` scales every element in a matrix a by coefficient k.

`a` is the `mat33` to scale.

`k` is the float to scale by.

This returns a `mat33` `a` scaled element-wise by `k`.

objects.name: subtract
objects.doc:
`subtract(a,b)` subtracts one `mat33` from another `mat33`.

`a` is the minuend.

`b` is the subtraherd.

This returns a `mat33` formed by the element-wise subtraction of `b` from `a`.

objects.name: transform_point
objects.doc:
`transform_point( a, v )` transforms a `vec2` point by a `mat33`.

`a` is a `mat33` used to transform the point.

`v` is a `vec2` to be transformed.

This returns a `vec2` representing the application of `a` to `v`.

The point `a` is internally treated as having a third coordinate equal to 1.0.

Note that transforming a point will work for all transforms.

objects.name: transform_vector
objects.doc:
`transform_vector( a, v )` transforms a `vec2` vector by a `mat33`.

`a` is a `mat33` used to transform the point.

`v` is a `vec2` to be transformed.

This returns a `vec2` representing the application of `a` to `v`.

The point `a` is internally treated as having a third coordinate equal to 0.0.

Note that transforming a vector will work for only rotations, scales, and shears.

objects.name: zero
objects.doc:
`zero()` creates a zeroed `mat33`.

This returns a zeroed `mat33`.

objects.name: add
objects.doc: `add(a,b)` adds one 4x4 matrix to another.

objects.name: apply
objects.doc: `apply( a, v )` transforms a vector `v` by a 4x4 matrix `a`.

objects.name: apply_left
objects.doc: `apply_left( v, a )` transforms a vector `v` by a 4x4 matrix `a`.

objects.name: apply_left_transpose
objects.doc: `apply_left_transpose( v, a )` transforms a vector `v` by a 4x4 matrix `a` transposed.

objects.name: apply_transpose
objects.doc: `apply_transpose( a, v )` transforms a vector `v` by a 4x4 matrix `a` transposed.

objects.name: at
objects.doc: `at( a, i, j)` selects the element of a 4x4 matrix at row i and column j.

objects.name: column0
objects.doc: `column0( a )` selects the first column from a matrix 4x4 as a vec4.

objects.name: column1
objects.doc: `column1( a )` selects the second column from a matrix 4x4 as a vec4.

objects.name: column2
objects.doc: `column2( a )` selects the third column from a matrix 4x4 as a vec4.

objects.name: column3
objects.doc: `column3( a )` selects the fourth column from a matrix 4x4 as a vec4.

objects.name: diag
objects.doc: `diag( a )` selects the diagonal from a matrix 4x4 as a vec4.

objects.name: identity
objects.doc: `identity()` creates a 4x4 identity matrix.

objects.name: make_rotate_x
objects.doc: `make_rotate_x( theta )` creates a mat44 that rotates a vec3 by `theta` radians about the X axis.

objects.name: make_rotate_y
objects.doc: `make_rotate_y( theta )` creates a mat44 that rotates a vec3 by `theta` radians about the Y axis.

objects.name: make_rotate_z
objects.doc: `make_rotate_z( theta )` creates a mat44 that rotates a vec3 by `theta` radians about the Z axis.

objects.name: make_scale
objects.doc: `make_scale( k )` creates a mat44 that uniformly scales by a value k.

objects.name: make_scale
objects.doc: `make_scale( sx, sy, sz, sw )` creates a mat44 that scales by sx, sy, sz, and sz.

objects.name: make_translate
objects.doc: `make_translate( tx, ty, tz )` creates a mat44 that translates a point by tx, ty, and tz.

objects.name: multiply
objects.doc: `multiply( a, b )` multiply two matrices a and b together.

objects.name: multiply_transpose
objects.doc: `multiply_transpose( a, b )` multiply two matrices a and b transpose together.

objects.name: round
objects.doc: `round( a, sigfigs )` rounds every element of a supplied mat44 `a` to number of digits `sigfigs`.

objects.name: row0
objects.doc: `row0( a )` selects the first row from a matrix 4x4 as a vec4.

objects.name: row1
objects.doc: `row1( a )` selects the second row from a matrix 4x4 as a vec4.

objects.name: row2
objects.doc: `row2( a )` selects the third row from a matrix 4x4 as a vec4.

objects.name: row3
objects.doc: `row3( a )` selects the fourth row from a matrix 4x4 as a vec4.

objects.name: scale
objects.doc: `scale( a, k )` scales every element in a matrix a by coefficient k.

objects.name: subtract
objects.doc: `subtract(a,b)` subtracts one 4x4 matrix from another..

objects.name: transform_point
objects.doc:
`transform_point( a, v )` transforms a vec3 point `v` by a matrix `a`.

The point `a` is internally treated as having a fourth coordinate equal to 1.0.

Note that transforming a point will work for all transforms.

objects.name: transform_vector
objects.doc:
`transform_vector( a, v )` transforms a vec3 vector `v` by a matrix `a`.

The point `a` is internally treated as having a fourth coordinate equal to 0.0.

Note that transforming a vector will work for only rotations, scales, and shears.

objects.name: zero
objects.doc: `zero()` creates a 4x4 zero matrix.

objects.name: add
objects.doc:
`add( a, b)` adds a vec2 (a) to a vec2 (b).

It returns a tuple of the form { ax + bx, ay + by }.

`add( a, b )` adds two `vec2`s.

`a` is the first `vec2`.

`b` is the second `vec2`.

It returns a `vec2` of the form { a<sub>x</sub> + b<sub>x</sub>, a<sub>y</sub> + b<sub>y</sub> }.

objects.name: create
objects.doc:
`create()` creates a zero vec2.

It will return a tuple of the form {0.0,0.0}.
`create()` creates a zeroed `vec2`.

It takes no arguments.

It returns a `vec2` of the form `{ 0.0, 0.0 }`.

objects.name: create
objects.doc:
`create(vec)` creates a `vec2` from a list of 2 or more floats.

`vec` is a list of 2 or more floats.

It returns a `vec2` of the form `{x,y}`, where `x` and `y` are the first three elements in `vec`.

objects.name: create
objects.doc:
`create(x,y)` creates a `vec2` of value (x,y).

`x` is the first element of the `vec3` to be created.

`y` is the second element of the `vec3` to be created.

It returns a `vec2` of the form `{x,y}`.

objects.name: dot
objects.doc:
`dot( a, b )` finds the dot (inner) product of one `vec2` with another `vec2`.

`a` is the first `vec2`.

`b` is the second `vec2`.

It returns a float of the value (a<sub>x</sub>b<sub>x</sub> + a<sub>y</sub>b<sub>y</sub> ).

objects.name: length
objects.doc:
`length(a)` finds the length (Eucldiean or L2 norm) of a `vec2`.

`a` is the `vec2` to find the length of.

It returns a float of the value (sqrt( a<sub>x</sub><sup>2</sup> + a<sub>y</sub><sup>2</sup>)).

objects.name: length_manhattan
objects.doc:
`length_manhattan(a)` finds the Manhattan (L1 norm) length of a `vec2`.

`a` is the `vec2` to find the Manhattan length of.

It returns a float of the value (a<sub>x</sub> + a<sub>y</sub>).

The Manhattan length is the sum of the components.

objects.name: length_squared
objects.doc:
`length_squared(a)` finds the square of the length of a vec2 (a).

In many cases, this is sufficient for comparisions and avaoids a sqrt.

It returns a float of the value (ax*ax + ay*ay).
`length_squared(a)` finds the square of the length of a `vec2`.

`a` is the `vec2` to find the length squared of.

It returns a float of the value a<sub>x</sub><sup>2</sup> + a<sub>y</sub><sup>2</sup>.

In many cases, this is sufficient for comparisons and avoids a square root.

objects.name: lerp
objects.doc:
`lerp(a,b,t)` is used to linearly interpolate between two given vectors a and b along an interpolant t.

The interpolant `t`  is on the domain [0,1]. Behavior outside of that is undefined.
`lerp(a,b,t)` linearly interpolates between one `vec2` and another `vec2` along an interpolant.

`a` is the starting `vec2`.

`b` is the ending `vec2`.

`t` is the interpolant float, on the domain [0,1].

It returns a `vec2` of the form (1-t)**a** - (t)**b**.

The interpolant `t` is on the domain [0,1]. Behavior outside of that is undefined.

objects.name: multiply
objects.doc:
`multiply( a, b)` mulitplies element-wise a vec2 (a) by a vec2 (b).

It returns a tuple of the form { ax*bx, ay*by }.
`multiply( a, b )` multiplies element-wise a `vec2` by another `vec2`.

`a` is the `vec2` multiplicand.

`b` is the `vec2` multiplier.

It returns a `vec2` of the form { a<sub>x</sub>b<sub>x</sub>, a<sub>y</sub>b<sub>y</sub> }.

objects.name: near
objects.doc:
`near(a,b, distance)` checks whether two `vec2`s are within a certain distance of each other.

`a` is the first `vec2`.

`b` is the second `vec2`.

`distance` is the distance between them as a float.

objects.name: normalize
objects.doc:
`normalize(a)` finds the unit vector with the same direction as a `vec2`.

`a` is the `vec2` to be normalized.

It returns a `vec2` of the form `{normx, normy}`.

This is done by dividing each component by the vector's magnitude.

objects.name: perp
objects.doc:
`perp(a)` creates a vector perpendicular to another vector `a`.

`a` is the `vec2` to be perpindicular to.

This returns a `vec2` perpindicular to `a`, to the right of the original `a`.

objects.name: perp_prod
objects.doc:
`perp_prod( a, b )` finds the perpindicular product of one `vec2` with another `vec2`.

`a` is the first `vec2`.

`b` is the second `vec2`.

The perpindicular product is the magnitude of the cross-product between the two vectors.

It returns a float of the value (a<sub>x</sub>b<sub>y</sub> - b<sub>x</sub>a<sub>y</sub>).

objects.name: project
objects.doc:
`project(a,b)` projects one `vec2` onto another `vec2`.

`a` is the first `vec2`.

`b` is the second `vec2`.

This returns a `vec2` representing the image of `a` in the direction of `b`.

objects.name: rotate
objects.doc:
`rotate(a,theta)` rotates a `vec2` CCW about the +Z axis.

`a` is the `vec2` to rotate.

`theta` is the number of radians to rotate by as a float.

This returns a `vec2`.

objects.name: scale
objects.doc:
`scale( a, scale )` uniformly scales a `vec2`.

`a` is the `vec2` to be scaled.

`scale` is the float to scale each element of `a` by.

It returns a tuple of the form { a<sub>x</sub>scale, a<sub>y</sub>scale }.

objects.name: subtract
objects.doc:
`subtract(a, b )` subtracts one `vec2` from another `vec2`.

`a` is the `vec2` minuend.

`b` is the `vec2` subtrahend.

It returns a `vec2` of the form { a<sub>x</sub> - b<sub>x</sub>, a<sub>y</sub> - b<sub>y</sub> }.

(the terminology was found [here](http://mathforum.org/library/drmath/view/58801.html)).

objects.name: add
objects.doc:
`add( a, b)` adds two `vec3`s.

`a` is the first `vec3`.

`b` is the second `vec3`.

It returns a `vec3` of the form { a<sub>x</sub> + b<sub>x</sub>, a<sub>y</sub> + b<sub>y</sub>, a<sub>z</sub> + b<sub>z</sub> }.

objects.name: create
objects.doc:
`create()` creates a zeroed `vec3`.

It takes no arguments.

It returns a `vec3` of the form `{ 0.0, 0.0, 0.0 }`.

objects.name: create
objects.doc:
`create(vec)` creates a `vec3` from a list of 3 or more floats.

`vec` is a list of 3 or more floats.

It returns a `vec3` of the form `{x,y,z}`, where `x`, `y`, and `z` are the first three elements in `vec`.

objects.name: create
objects.doc:
`create(x,y,z)` creates a `vec3` of value (x,y,z).

`x` is the first element of the `vec3` to be created.

`y` is the second element of the `vec3` to be created.

`z` is the third element of the `vec3` to be created.

It returns a `vec3` of the form `{x,y,z}`.

objects.name: cross
objects.doc:
`cross( a, b)` finds the cross productof one `vec3` with another `vec3`.

`a` is the first `vec3`.

`b` is the second `vec3`.

It returns a float of the value ( a<sub>y</sub>b<sub>z</sub> - a<sub>z</sub>b<sub>y</sub>, a<sub>z</sub>b<sub>x</sub> - a<sub>x</sub>b<sub>z</sub>, a<sub>x</sub>b<sub>y</sub> - a<sub>y</sub>b<sub>x</sub>).

The cross product of two vectors is a vector perpendicular to the two source vectors.
Its magnitude will be the area of the parallelogram made by the two souce vectors.

objects.name: dot
objects.doc:
`dot( a, b)` finds the dot (inner) product of one `vec3` with another `vec3`.

`a` is the first `vec3`.

`b` is the second `vec3`.

It returns a float of the value (a<sub>x</sub>b<sub>x</sub> + a<sub>y</sub>b<sub>y</sub> + a<sub>z</sub>b<sub>z</sub>).

objects.name: length
objects.doc:
`length(a)` finds the length (Eucldiean or L2 norm) of a `vec3`.

`a` is the `vec3` to find the length of.

It returns a float of the value (sqrt( a<sub>x</sub><sup>2</sup> + a<sub>y</sub><sup>2</sup> + a<sub>z</sub><sup>2</sup>)).

objects.name: length_manhattan
objects.doc:
`length_manhattan(a)` finds the Manhattan (L1 norm) length of a `vec3`.

`a` is the `vec3` to find the Manhattan length of.

It returns a float of the value (a<sub>x</sub> + a<sub>y</sub> + a<sub>z</sub>).

The Manhattan length is the sum of the components.

objects.name: length_squared
objects.doc:
`length_squared(a)` finds the square of the length of a `vec3`.

`a` is the `vec3` to find the length squared of.

It returns a float of the value a<sub>x</sub><sup>2</sup> + a<sub>y</sub><sup>2</sup> + a<sub>z</sub><sup>2</sup>.

In many cases, this is sufficient for comparisons and avoids a square root.

objects.name: lerp
objects.doc:
`lerp(a,b,t)` linearly interpolates between one `vec3` and another `vec3` along an interpolant.

`a` is the starting `vec3`.

`b` is the ending `vec3`.

`t` is the interpolant float, on the domain [0,1].

It returns a `vec3` of the form (1-t)**a** - (t)**b**.

The interpolant `t` is on the domain [0,1]. Behavior outside of that is undefined.

objects.name: multiply
objects.doc:
`multiply( a, b)` multiplies element-wise a `vec3` by another `vec3`.

`a` is the `vec3` multiplicand.

`b` is the `vec3` multiplier.

It returns a `vec3` of the form { a<sub>x</sub>b<sub>x</sub>, a<sub>y</sub>b<sub>y</sub>, a<sub>z</sub>b<sub>z</sub> }.

objects.name: near
objects.doc:
`near(a,b, distance)` checks whether two `vec3`s are within a certain distance of each other.

`a` is the first `vec3`.

`b` is the second `vec3`.

`distance` is the distance between them as a float.

objects.name: normalize
objects.doc:
`normalize(a)` finds the unit vector with the same direction as a `vec3`.

`a` is the `vec3` to be normalized.

It returns a `vec3` of the form `{normx, normy, normz}`.

This is done by dividing each component by the vector's magnitude.

objects.name: rotate
objects.doc:
`rotate( v, k, theta)` rotates a vector (v) about a unit vector (k) by theta radians.

`v` is the `vec3` to be rotated.

`k` is the `vec3` axis of rotation. *It must be of unit length*.

`theta` is the angle in radians to rotate as a float.

This uses the [Formula of Rodriguez](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rodrigues%27_rotation_formula):

**V**<sub>rot</sub> = **V**cos(theta) + (**K** x **V**)sin(theta) + **K**(**K** dot **V**)(1-cos(theta))

objects.name: scale
objects.doc:
`scale( a, scale)` uniformly scales a `vec3`.

`a` is the `vec3` to be scaled.

`scale` is the float to scale each element of `a` by.

It returns a tuple of the form { a<sub>x</sub>scale, a<sub>y</sub>scale, a<sub>z</sub>scale }.

objects.name: subtract
objects.doc:
`subtract(a, b)` subtracts one `vec3` from another `vec3`.

`a` is the `vec3` minuend.

`b` is the `vec3` subtrahend.

It returns a `vec3` of the form { a<sub>x</sub> - b<sub>x</sub>, a<sub>y</sub> - b<sub>y</sub>, a<sub>z</sub> - b<sub>z</sub> }.

(the terminology was found [here](http://mathforum.org/library/drmath/view/58801.html)).
